segments.text: She climbed from the cliff, through the balcony, and found Dad David there with a cup of coffee in his hand, nestled in a wicker chair as he gazed at the sea.
He surely saw her.
He smiled at her gently.
Want some coffee?
No thank you, she replied, and sat next to him.
This is one of the most magical places I've seen in my life.
Dan calls it a piece of paradise, and it's not just a saying.
The location of this house and what you filled it with are a winning combination.
I don't know how to thank you for hosting me here and making me feel at home."
He looked at her with concentration and seriousness.
Look, I must say a few words and please don't see it as interference in your life, he suddenly said.
You've entered not just our home but also our hearts.
Naomi and I couldn't stop talking about you last night before bed.
There's no doubt you've been through a tough time, and maybe you're still going through it.
But I want you to know, regardless of Dan, whenever you want, our home is open to you and you can come by unannounced.
If you need help, good advice, or anything else, we're here."
She was moved to tears and tried to breathe deeply.
He noticed.
You already know where everything is, even where the iron is, so what could possibly happen?
He said half jokingly.
In a choked emotional voice, she thanked him and promised to remember.
She slowly rose from her seat to go to her room.
He stood up too.
Out of courtesy, she had already started walking towards the room, then suddenly turned back, approached him and hugged him.
Thank you for everything, she said and left.
Only in her room behind the closed door did she let the tears fall freely down her cheeks.
The warmth and kindness surrounding her in this house only highlighted the profound loneliness she had lived in.
Until now, she hadn't stopped to think about it, burying it behind walls.
And now, suddenly, she realized more clearly with each moment that the way she was living wasn't entirely normal.
She went into the shower and let the water wash over her, including the thoughts racing in her mind.
After the shower, she slipped back into her jeans and t-shirt and headed to the kitchen to make breakfast.
No one was around, not even Dad David.
By the time they gathered, the table on the terrace was already set and all that was left for her to do was make the omelets.
Strangely, they weren't surprised.
They had already gotten used to it.
The coffee is on you, she said to Dan.
He laughed.
I thought my job was to dry the dishes.
Sometimes in life it's both, she replied with a relaxed smile.
Now everyone was laughing.
As he headed to the kitchen, she added, on second thought, I'd like a hot chocolate if there's any.
Well then, he said, I should have guessed, every age in its drink, and so the day continued in comfort and leisure.
She picked a book from the large library, intending to sit on the porch facing the sea and read.
But on her way there, she encountered the piano again, beckoning her, and she couldn't resist.
She sat before it and began playing softly to herself.
Without her noticing, Mom Naomi came out of nowhere, curled up and secretly enjoyed herself in the adjacent armchair.
There was a boy, a very strange, enchanted boy.
They say he wandered very far, very far.
over land and sea, a little shy and sad of eye, but very wise was he, and then one day, a magic day, he passed my way, and while we spoke of many things, fools and kings, this he said to me.
In the building next to the horse stables, Dan and Dad David were trying to repair a lawnmower engine.
They work together in the camaraderie of a team that knows what it's doing.
Their hands black with machine oil, but their eyes shining with enjoyment, joking with each other.
The sound of the piano reached them, and Dad David added his deep, baritone voice, singing along with her, completing the line.
The greatest thing you'll ever learn is just to love and be loved in return.
He looked at Dan and suddenly said, I don't know what's between you two, but there's no doubt she's a very special girl.
Be very careful not to hurt her.
Dad, you've taken it too far.
Until two days ago, she was just our temporary serious duty officer.
I knew nothing about her except that she could be trusted with closed eyes.
She's a welfare officer who with her diligence got involved in everything and the commander temporarily made her the duty officer when ours got sick.
You could tell by her eyes that she was capable.
I gave her a lift and fell asleep at the wheel.
Then she took over and let me sleep like a rock beside her.

After a few hours when I woke up, I found myself alone in the jeep, covered with a blanket and some parking lot with a big note on the windshield directing me to enter through the open door on my left.
It was getting dark and I heard faint, familiar piano notes from afar, attuned by Sinatra.
I walked through the door into a wonderland, seeing in front of me a dining room with beautiful wooden tables and chairs and charming paintings on the walls.
The floor was still wet from mopping, and I stood like a fool, staring at her without her noticing.
She was so absorbed in her quiet playing that it felt like stepping into a fairy tale scene.
When she noticed my presence, she abruptly stopped playing in great embarrassment.
led me to one of the hotel rooms so that I could shower and come back to eat from the dish she had prepared, whose aroma filled the house.
No one else was around.
And suddenly, before we sat down, some veterinarian, one of the hotel's regular guests, appeared and sat to eat with us.
When I mentioned that she drove us here because I almost left us in a ditch, I saw he gave her a reproachful look and she lowered her eyes with a hint of a smile.
Only later did I hear them whispering and realize she doesn't even have a license and was just afraid we'd overturn the vehicle if I fell asleep.
He's the one who taught her to drive, and she drives excellently.
I was so tired that I asked to rent an empty room, but she said absolutely not that I should just stay and sleep and she'd sleep better knowing I wasn't seeking a ditch by the side of the road.
The next morning I found her working in the garden.
A large garden surrounds this pink house.
It's well maintained and blooming.
A delightful display of silver baskets, pansies, and a huge China berry tree standing in the middle.
Everything around is clean and cared for.

I realized that during the hours I slept in the jeep, she had mopped the entire dining room, set something to cook, cleaned the rooms, changed towels and sheets, washed some things, including her uniform, and hung them on the line, and now here she was, tending the garden as well.
When we finished breakfast and she intended to send me on my way, it suddenly occurred to me that she could use a rest.
All the soldiers in the unit go home to motherly pampering, with someone doing their laundry and cooking for them.
And I realized that what stood before my eyes was a mature and fully independent young woman, seemingly living alone in a small, charming hotel.
taking care of her own needs and those of the few guests who stayed there.
Something was utterly surreal about this whole situation.
And I realized I knew very little about her.
But slowly I began to understand that beyond everything she possessed rare qualities and courage, a lot of courage.
And then we discovered that her mother had passed away a few years ago.
So where's her painting dad?
Where did he disappear to?
And who's watching over her?
If anyone at all.
In any case, she definitely got to my heart.
I admit I hadn't really seen her before.
Hidden in her oversized military uniform.
Not trying to charm or beautify.
Just doing her job with serious and profound responsibility.
Worrying about soldiers with any personal issue they had.
Understanding their hearts.
Even making home visits with supplies the commander sent.
And she, she hid her own life.
Guarding her privacy fiercely.
Only now am I starting to understand why.
It seems there's a story here.
Far more complex than we realize.
I won't push her, but I know the moment will come when she'll share more.
He paused for a moment, his face softening.
And how didn't I see she's so lovely?
He said to himself.
And how did she suddenly become such a close friend in less than two days?
And I feel like I can joke with her, lightly and with the good spirit that exists only between old friends.
And why on earth do I have this instinct to protect her?
From what?
Dad David didn't utter a sound during Dan's entire monologue.
He understood what his son hadn't yet grasped, but didn't say a word about it.
He was glad about the straightforward girl who had entered their lives with all her warmth, maturity, and uniqueness.
They were already sleepless with worry for their son, so at least he should have a warm spot in his soul.
Whatever may develop from this would be a welcome addition.
He is older than she is by a few years.
Though with everything she's been through, sometimes she seems the oldest in the group.
Over the years, he's had a few relationships.
Often, they were the ones who initiated and they ended quickly, mainly because of his intensive military career.
But here, even before it really started, something entirely different seemed to be happening.
He watched his son with great love, who has long become a man.
with his slightly mischievous look.
The worry lines on his brow and the seriousness in his gaze, the sun wrinkles that appeared when he smiled and suddenly, out of nowhere, he said, take care of her son, someone needs to.
The next day, at five in the morning, they set off.
The night before, they had said emotional goodbyes to Dan's parents with hugs.
She hadn't forgotten the conversation with Dan's dad on the balcony, knowing she had a reserved spot in this little piece of paradise.
It wasn't yet fully light.
The sun had just risen, and the surrounding light was so special.
They drove south.
They didn't even turn on the radio.
a kind of blessed silence, not oppressive, between them.
They drove like that quietly, not speaking.
Occasionally they exchanged a glance with a gentle smile, but when they passed the turnoff to Beersheva, he suddenly reached out and grasped her hand.
His hand was warm and kind, and her hand rested in it happily.
They still hadn't spoken to each other, only looked into each other's eyes.
The warmth exchanged between their hands and eyes seemed natural.
She was calm, feeling that his grip on her hand came from a place of care and ran through her mind was what had happened to them in the past two days.
From the serious, responsible commander who spoke little and focused on the essentials, he suddenly turned into a close friend with human warmth and a sense of humor.
He turned out to be a lover of books and animals and the sea, just like her.
And she knew she liked his tousled curls that gave him a mischievous look, especially when he smiled a cheeky smile.
She hadn't really seen him before, but now she felt there was something about his behavior that sought to protect her.
She remembered the hand he placed on her shoulder during that dramatic and emotional moment with the French ambassador, and even before that, when he realized she was in dire need of rest.
Even she didn't understand how much.
Only her secrets lay between them.
Now perhaps a little less, after some of them were revealed in the process.
But she wasn't sure he fully understood.
She would have to explain a lot to him when the time came.
But her heart felt warmth for him.
Her hand remained in his, and as they neared the base, he turned to her, looked deep into her eyes, and a soft smile spread across his face.
A new week begins, he said, different from any we've known before.
I just want you to know these last two days were wonderful for me.
And I have all the patience in the world for whatever comes next.
He turned her palm in his hand, brought it to his lips, and kissed it gently.
God, she thought, how much emotion there is in this gesture.
She closed her eyes for a moment, with excitement, and discovered they were slightly moist.
Then returned his gaze warmly and said, In a hoarse voice, Me too!
From that moment they were again the commander and the temporary duty officer, dressed sharply in their uniforms.
When they stopped at the entrance to the commander's office, they already wore serious and responsible expressions.
She slowly got out of the jeep, waved goodbye to him, and made her way to her room, knowing he was still there watching her.
